title: 104_hr494
content: The Act titled as the "Economic Development Loan Assistance Demonstration Program Act of 1995" establishes a demonstration program. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will implement a program to promote economic development in enterprise communities by providing grants to community development corporations to lower interest rates on loans for economic activities. The program will be conducted in 5 selected enterprise communities, with at least 2 in rural areas and 2 in other locations. The Secretary will select enterprise communities for a program promoting economic development, ensuring geographic diversity. Grants for economic development loan assistance. Under this Act, the Secretary may grant funds to community development corporations to reduce interest rates on loans for businesses and nonprofits in enterprise communities. The grant amounts should not exceed a 60% reduction in interest rates. The Secretary may grant funds to community development corporations to reduce interest rates on loans for businesses and nonprofits in enterprise communities by up to 60 percent of the market rate. Actions will be taken to inform businesses and nonprofits about the availability of these loans. The Secretary will monitor grant usage and administration costs under this Act. Additionally, reports and studies will be conducted. The Secretary will submit an annual report to Congress evaluating the effectiveness of grants under the demonstration program. A study will be conducted on the effects and costs of a long-term, expanded grant program, with a report due by September 30, 1998. A report on the study results and recommendations for implementing a program described in the previous paragraph is due by September 30, 1998. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "economic development activities" and "enterprise community." SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. This section authorizes appropriations for the Act. SEC. 7 authorizes $100,000,000 for fiscal years 1996-1998. SEC. 8 allows the Secretary to issue necessary regulations.
